dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Did you see Mike Pompeo's accusation that China is meddling in the midterm elections?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Did you see Mike Pompeo's accusation that China is meddling in the midterm elections?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vice President Mike Pence launched a cannonball across the bow of Chinas ship of state last week. He said the country was meddling in the midterm elections.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he specifically said they want President Biden gone through impeachment. That's a huge claim.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he specifically said they want President Biden gone through impeachment. That's a huge claim.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He said the country was meddling in the midterm elections. They want President Trump gone in an impeachment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really sets up a scenario for sanctions, especially under those executive orders Trump signed, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really sets up a scenario for sanctions, especially under those executive orders Trump signed, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If China was meddling, it sets the table for Washington to sanction them under two new executive orders signed by Trump and the August 2017 Countering Americas Adversaries Through Sanctions Act.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—the 2017 Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act could come into play here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-the twenty seventeen Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act could come into play here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If China was meddling, it sets the table for Washington to sanction them under two new executive orders signed by Trump and the August 2017 Countering Americas Adversaries Through Sanctions Act.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's this weird contrast—Pence was in Beijing making progress on trade and policy talks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's this weird contrast-Pence was in Beijing making progress on trade and policy talks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Top diplomats on both sides said Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was getting nowhere with this Chinese counterparts. He said they were fundamental disagreements over a range of issues from trade to Chinas domestic and foreign policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the Shanghai stock indexes actually rose almost 5% after the holiday. That's not nothing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the Shanghai stock indexes actually rose almost five percent after the holiday. That's not nothing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following a weeklong holiday in China, mainland equities fell by as much as 4.7% in some Shanghai stock indexes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the ASHR ETF is up over 22% this year. U.S. funds are pouring into Chinese equities now that they're in the MSCI index.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the A S H R E T F is up over twenty two percent this year. U.S. funds are pouring into Chinese equities now that they're in the M S C I index.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The China A-shares (ASHR) are down over 22% year-to-date, a sorry state of affairs for dozens of U.S. mutual funds benchmarked to the MSCI Emerging Markets Index and who have been mandated to reallocate a portion of portfolio funds to mainland China equities now that they are part of the MSCI EM.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then Foreign Minister Wang Li accused Washington of escalating trade conflicts and interfering with Taiwan. He said it's hurting mutual trust.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then Foreign Minister Wang Li accused Washington of escalating trade conflicts and interfering with Taiwan. He said it's hurting mutual trust.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi accused Washington of escalating the trade conflict, interfering with Taiwan, and leveling false accusations against China regarding election interference and inserting chips in Apple products in order to spy on U.S. companies. These actions [have hurt] our mutual trust, and cast a shadow over the future of China-U.S. relations, he was quoted saying yesterday by the South China Morning Post.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like both sides are talking past each other. Even the 3,600-word paper Beijing released praises cooperation but also calls out U.S. policies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like both sides are talking past each other. Even the three thousand, six hundred-word paper Beijing released praises cooperation but also calls out U.S. policies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Beijing recently released a 36,000-word paper on representing the official view on U.S. trade frictions, published on Xinhua News Agency on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Finance Minister Liu Kun mentioned they're raising $189 billion in taxes this year to handle trade war impacts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Finance Minister Liu Kun mentioned they're raising one hundred eighty nine dollars billion in taxes this year to handle trade war impacts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He said China is equipped to handle it and would cut around $189 billion in taxes over the course of this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Macquarie economists say China's stimulus is proactive—ahead of the curve, even.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Macquarie economists say China's stimulus is proactive-ahead of the curve, even.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Macquarie Capital economists Larry Hu and Irene Wu wrote in a recent note that Chinese policymakers remain reactive, not proactive in conducting stimulus and add that Beijings policy loosening is still way behind the curve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's this push from groups like B20 criticizing state-owned enterprises, and China's trade council wants revisions before the G20 summit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's this push from groups like B20 criticizing state-owned enterprises, and China's trade council wants revisions before the G20 summit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Business 20 issued a note last week calling for an end to state-related competitive distortions, but the wording met with strong objections from the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade, a semigovernmental trade advocacy group. They insisted that the B20 proposal should not be submitted to G20 leaders at the Argentina meetup in November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So we've got sanctions threats, stock market gains, and diplomatic friction all at once. How does that even compute?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So we've got sanctions threats, stock market gains, and diplomatic friction all at once. How does that even compute?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like a high-stakes game where both economies are intertwined but politically at odds. Something's gotta give.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like a high-stakes game where both economies are intertwined but politically at odds. Something's gotta give.

artist_script:
HostA: Did you see Mike Pompeo's accusation that China is meddling in the midterm elections?
HostB: Yeah, and he specifically said they want President Biden gone through impeachment. That’s a huge claim.
HostA: It really sets up a scenario for sanctions, especially under those executive orders Trump signed, right?
HostB: Exactly—the 2017 Countering America’s Adversaries Through Sanctions Act could come into play here.
HostA: But then there’s this weird contrast—Pence was in Beijing making progress on trade and policy talks.
HostB: Right, and the Shanghai stock indexes actually rose almost 5% after the holiday. That’s not nothing.
HostA: And the ASHR ETF is up over 22% this year. U.S. funds are pouring into Chinese equities now that they’re in the MSCI index.
HostB: But then Foreign Minister Wang Li accused Washington of escalating trade conflicts and interfering with Taiwan. He said it’s hurting mutual trust.
HostA: It’s like both sides are talking past each other. Even the 3,600-word paper Beijing released praises cooperation but also calls out U.S. policies.
HostB: And Finance Minister Liu Kun mentioned they’re raising $189 billion in taxes this year to handle trade war impacts.
HostA: Macquarie economists say China’s stimulus is proactive—ahead of the curve, even.
HostB: But then there’s this push from groups like B20 criticizing state-owned enterprises, and China’s trade council wants revisions before the G20 summit.
HostA: So we’ve got sanctions threats, stock market gains, and diplomatic friction all at once. How does that even compute?
HostB: It feels like a high-stakes game where both economies are intertwined but politically at odds. Something’s gotta give.
